awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Develop Robust Light-Scattering Computational Capability Based on the Method of Separation of Variables in Spheroidal Coordinates for Small-to-Large Spheroids
awd_abstract_narration:
Dust aerosols affect global climate by partially absorbing and reflecting incoming sunlight and heat energy emitted by the atmosphere and the surface. The optical properties of dust particles are critical to reducing uncertainties in the current knowledge of the role of dust aerosols in the climate system, and thus are important for predicting future climate. The dust particle optical properties are also fundamental for inferring dust aerosol characteristics from space-borne and ground-based remote sensing observations. Dust particles are almost exclusively nonspherical. It has been extensively demonstrated that the spheroidal particle shape model represents a quantum leap forward, compared to the spherical model, for computing the optical properties of nonspherical particles. At present, the optical properties of small-to-large particles can be computed only for spheres. There is a pressing need to have an exact and robust computational capability to compute the optical properties of spheroidal particles. Leveraging advances in computational mathematics, advances in electromagnetic scattering theories, and modern computer technologies and computer coding techniques, this project aims to develop a novel program to compute the optical properties of spheroidal particle in the small-to-large particle size range. Because many bacteria, microweeds, oceanic particles, and interstellar dust particles have approximately spheroidal shapes, the outcome of this project will also find extensive applications in climate science (particularly the radiative energy budget in the climate system), remote sensing, industry, bio-optics, oceanic optics, astrophysics, planetary sciences, and other fields beyond atmospheric sciences. Because this project focuses on a major unsolved interdisciplinary problem and because of significant challenges, particularly from the perspective of computational electromagnetics and mathematics, this project is exploratory but potentially transformative, i.e., “high risk – high payoff”. In addition to its scientific merit, this project contains an educational component to train an early-career researcher in the interdisciplinary area mentioned above. 

This project aims to solve light scattering by a spheroid in spheroidal coordinates. Although solving the electromagnetic wave equation via the method of separation of variables in spheroid coordinates has been explored, the previously developed models are applicable only to particles that are small with respect to the incident wavelength and have little practical use. The major challenge encountered by the previous effort is numerical instability of spheroidal harmonic functions. This project will seek to achieve numerical stability of spheroidal harmonic functions by using advanced algorithms, such as expressing spheroidal functions in terms of the Wigner-d function. The key to computing spheroidal functions is to find eigenvalues of corresponding spheroidal equations. The radial and angular spheroidal equations are of the Sturm-Liouville type. The eigenvalues will be calculated by the invariant-imbedding method, which is expected to be numerically stable and accurate. Thus, the spheroidal functions are expected to be accurate even with extreme parameters. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a numerically stable capability for accurately computing the optical properties of a spheroid beyond the currently applicable particle size and aspect ratio ranges of other existing computational capabilities, such as the discrete dipole approximation method (DDA), the finite-difference time domain (FDTD) method, the extended boundary condition method (EBCM), and the invariant imbedding T-matrix method (IITM).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this project, the Texas A&M University team led by the PI developed an analytical approach and an associated computer program for simulations of the optical properties of dielectric particles with spheroidal shapes. Many studies reported in the literature treated nonspherical dust aerosol particles and hailstone particles as spheres, leading to significant errors and even misleading results. The spheroidal model represents a considerable improvement compared to the spherical model, as the spheroid geometry offers two degrees of freedom (particle size and the aspect ratio, i.e., the ratio of the particle's maximum dimension to its minimum dimension) while the spherical geometry offers only one degree of freedom (i.e., particle size). This project was mainly focused on a) deriving the formulas of an analytical solution to calculate the optical properties of spheroids, b) developing a computer program to accurately and efficiently implement the derived formulas and the corresponding algorithm, c) computing optical properties of spheroidal particles with various sizes, aspect ratios and refractive indices, and d) comparing with results by other independent methods. The project accomplishments are expected to significantly improve our capability to simulate the optical properties of spheroidal particles and enrich our knowledge of the optical properties of spheroids.

The analytical solution is derived from Maxwell’s equations and the separation of variables method (SVM) in spheroidal coordinates. The most innovative idea in this derivation is to use a numerically more stable function, referred to as the Wigner-d function, to replace the associated Legendre polynomial in constructing a key function of the analytical solution, called an angular spheroidal function. The new formulation based on the Wigner-d function is different from those in previous studies and is found to be more numerically stable in numerical implementation.

A FORTRAN-90 computational program was developed with state-of-the-art numerical algorithms to compute the radial spheroidal function. This allows practical calculations for particles that are more than 20 times larger than those based on previous analytical methods, both in terms of particle sizes or for particles that are highly elongated (resembling a football) or significantly flattened.

This project compares the present computed optical properties with those computed with T-matrix methods. The T-matrix method cannot be applied to very large spheroids or spheroids with an extreme aspect ratio. In contrast, the SVM is not limited by aspect ratio extremality and is applicable for very large particle sizes. We also compare our computed optical properties with the solutions provided with the approximate geometric optics method that is found to be accurate for large spheroids, except for backscattering computations.

The major research outcomes of this project are summarized in a referred journal publication (Ding, J., P. Yang, 2023: Lorenz-Mie theory-type solution for light scattering by spheroids with small-to-large size parameters and aspect ratios. Optics Express, 31, 40937-40951).

Note: the above publication is highlighted in [ELSNEWSLETTER] Light Scattering Newsletter, issue 116, stating “Ding and Yang developed an advanced computational capability based on the separation of variables method (SVM) in spheroidal coordinates to compute the optical properties of spheroids with small-to-large sizes compared to the wavelength of the incident light. The method is applicable to spheroids with size parameters up to at least 600, and is essentially not restricted by particle aspect ratios. This accomplishment represents a breakthrough in solving the optical properties of a nonspherical particle in an analytical form.”

The project accomplishments are useful in numerous disciplines requiring knowledge of light scattering by particles, including atmospheric radiative transfer, remote sensing, climate science, astrophysics, planetary sciences, and bio-optics. The spheroidal shape model can largely capture the nonspherical effects on the optical properties. The computational program developed in this project will contribute specially to enhancing our knowledge of nonspherical dust aerosols, and reduce the uncertainties of dust aerosol radiative forcing effects in aerosol remote sensing and climate studies.
